[SYNTAX]: Overly complex sentence structures with multiple nested clauses (e.g., "However—to return to the war zone. I made no attempt...").
[LEXICON]: Archaic vocabulary/phrasing ("sauf conduit," "permis de séjour") may slightly impede modern readability.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shifts between narrative threads (e.g., critique of American embassies, tangential asides about society).
[STRUCTURE]: Minor disjointedness in scene changes (e.g., Meaux description feels somewhat disconnected from permit struggles).

[SYNTAX]: Abrupt inclusion of unrelated sci-fi dialogue ("But the ship's swooping...") disrupts narrative flow.
[TRANSITION]: Sudden shift from war context to futuristic quote without contextual bridge.

[STRUCTURE]: Unintroduced character dialogue ("Marie...") lacks setup or connection to preceding narrative.
[LOGIC]: Sci-fi elements ("hyper-space") contradict and disrupt historical war setting.

[SYNTAX]: Occasionally complex sentence structures may slightly impede immediate clarity, though overall syntax is well-managed.

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from descriptive war-town narrative to philosophical/historical quotes (e.g., Wordsworth, Bahá'u'lláh) without clear contextual bridges.
[STRUCTURE]: Tangential inclusion of non-localized reflections (e.g., Germany’s mission, divine imagery) disrupts focus on the hotel/hotel-life theme.

[SYNTAX]: Awkward sentence structure (e.g., "Turpentine I felt would avail not in this hotel...")

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from philosophical opening to narrative
[STRUCTURE]: Unrelated historical reference (American Civil War in WWI context)

[SYNTAX]: Minor awkward phrasing in a few complex sentences (e.g., "If I was forced to complain...").
[LEXICON]: Occasional overly formal vocabulary may slightly impede readability for modern readers.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transition from the farmer’s wife anecdote to the narrator’s War Office interactions.
[LOGIC]: Non-sequitur paragraph about ancient toolmaking ("Wood was worked with stone...") disrupts thematic coherence.

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt transition to burial customs description
[TRANSITION]: Disconnected shift to California reconstruction project

[SYNTAX]: Awkward phrasing (e.g., "on march" instead of "on the march").

[STRUCTURE]: Abrupt shifts between locations/topics (e.g., MILKI-EL quote, Paris anecdote).
[TRANSITION]: Lack of clear connectors between paragraphs.

[SYNTAX]: Complex, winding sentence structures in some paragraphs (e.g., narrator’s intent in France).
[TRANSITION]: Minor abrupt shifts between vignettes (e.g., from ultimatum to train scene).

[STRUCTURE]: Disjointed transitions between unrelated wartime scenes (e.g., German ultimatum, society formation, personal anecdotes).
[LOGIC]: Lack of explicit thematic links between segments (e.g., military train description feels tangential).

[GRAMMAR]: Incorrect verb tense ("has destroyed" instead of "had destroyed")
[SYNTAX]: Wordy/awkward phrasing (e.g., "If the delicacies always craved by the sick will raise the spirits...")
[CLARITY]: Ambiguous phrasing ("covers the top of a bathtub")

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from hospital description to bathtub detail
[STRUCTURE]: Tangential anecdote (woman with floating kidney) disrupts focus
[LOGIC]: Sudden "America first" reference without contextual buildup

[LEXICON]: Minor awkward phrasing (e.g., "to the verge of futility").

[TRANSITION]: Slight abruptness between thematic shifts (e.g., quotes to hospital description).
